tn.text: Here understanding something is spoken of as if it were being seen. AT: "the people realized"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The word "come" strengthens the force of the command following it. The people were demanding that Aaron make an idol for them.
"lead us" or "be our leader"
The word "them" refers to the golden rings.
This refers to all the people who rejected Moses as their leader and Moses' God as their God.

tn.ref: fashioned it in a mold, and made it into a molded calf
tn.text: Aaron melted the gold and poured it into a mold that had the shape of a calf. When the gold became hard, he removed the mold, and the hardened gold had the shape of a calf.
"When Aaron saw what the people did" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"to have a wild party." The people likely behaved in sexually immoral ways at the party.

tn.ref: left the way that I commanded them
tn.text: Here God speaks of the people disobeying what he commanded them as if he had told them to walk on a certain road and they left that road.  AT: "stopped doing what I commanded them to do" or "have stopped obeying what I commanded them to do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: They have molded for themselves a calf
tn.text: "They have made a gold statue for themselves shaped like a calf"
Here Yahweh compares knowing the people to seeing them. AT: "I know this people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
necked people** - Yahweh speaks of the people being stubborn as if they had stiff necks. AT: "a stubborn people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The word "now" is used here to mark a break in what Yahweh was telling Moses. Here Yahweh tells what he will do to the people.

tn.ref: My anger will burn hot against them
tn.text: Yahweh speaks of his anger as if it were a fire that could burn hot. AT: "My anger towards them will be terrible" or "I am extremely angry with them" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The word "you" refers to Moses. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

tn.ref: why does your anger burn against your people
tn.text: Moses used this question to to try to persuade Yahweh not to be so angry with his people. This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement. AT: "Do not let your anger burn against your people" or "Do not be so angry with your people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]]) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
These two phrases share similar meanings and are combined for emphasis. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
Here the word "hand" refers to the things Yahweh did. AT: "and the powerful things you did" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Moses continues to reason with God not to destroy Israel.

tn.ref: Why should the Egyptians say, 'He led them out ... to destroy them from the face of the earth?'
tn.text: Moses used this question to try to persuade God not to destroy his people. This rhetorical question can be translated with a statement. AT: If you destroy your people, the Egyptians might say, 'He led them out ... to destroy them from the face of the earth.' (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
"from the surface of the earth" or "from the earth"
"Stop your burning anger" or "Stop being so angry"
Moses speaks of God's anger as if it were a fire that was burning. AT: "your terrible anger" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"Remember Abraham" or "Think about Abraham"
"made an oath" or "solemnly promised"
God speaks about them possessing the land as if they would inherit it. AT: "They will possess it forever" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
These are the two stone slabs on which God had engraved his commandments.

tn.ref: The tablets were God's own work, and the writing was God's own writing
tn.text: These two phrases share similar meanings. The second explains how the tablets were "God's own work." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
It is assumed that Joshua met Moses while Moses was going back to the camp. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"the two stone slabs that Yahweh had written on"

tn.ref: Then Moses said to Aaron, "What did this people ... a great sin on them?"
tn.text: This can be stated as an indirect quote. AT: "Then Moses asked Aaron what the people do to him, that he have brought such a great sin on them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])

tn.ref: you have brought such a great sin on them
tn.text: Moses spoke of causing people to sin as if sin were an object and Aaron put it on them. AT: "you have caused them to sin so terribly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Do not let your anger burn hot
tn.text: Aaron spoke of Moses' anger as if it were a fire that could burn. "Do not be so angry" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: they are set on doing evil
tn.text: Being determined to do evil is spoken of as being set on evil. AT: "they are determined to do what is evil" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
People showed disrespect by putting the word "this" before his name, as if Moses were someone they did not know and could not trust.

tn.ref: So I said to them, 'Whoever has any gold, let him take it off.'
tn.text: This can be stated as an indirect quote. AT: "So I told them that whoever had any gold should take it off" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])

tn.ref: I threw it into the fire, and out came this calf
tn.text: Instead of taking ownership for making the calf, Aaron claims the calf came out of the fire supernaturally.
"were behaving wildly" or "were not controlling themselves"

tn.ref: Then Moses stood at the entrance ... "Whoever is on Yahweh's side, come to me."
tn.text: This can be stated as an indirect quote. AT: "Then Moses stood at the entrance to the camp and said that whoever was on Yahweh's side should come to him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])
Moses speaks of being loyal to Yahweh as being on Yahweh's side. AT: "Whoever is loyal to Yahweh"  or "Whoever serves Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: go back and forth from entrance to entrance
tn.text: "go in and out from one entrance of the camp to the other entrance" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"3000 of the people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: You have been placed into Yahweh's service
tn.text: This probably means "You have been chosen to serve Yahweh" or "You have become Yahweh's servants."

tn.ref: for each of you has taken action against his son and his brother
tn.text: The fact that they did this in obedience to God can be stated clearly. AT: "for you have obeyed Yahweh and killed your sons and your brothers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: You have committed a very great sin
tn.text: They worshiped an idol.

tn.ref: Perhaps I can make atonement for your sin
tn.text: Moses spoke of persuading God to forgive the people as if he could make atonement for their sin. AT: "Perhaps I can persuade Yahweh to forgive you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: blot me out of the book
tn.text: The word "me" here refers to the name of Moses. AT: "erase my name from the book"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: the book that you have written
tn.text: What God had written in the book can be stated clearly. AT: "the book in which you have written the names of your people" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: that person I will blot out of my book
tn.text: The phrase "that person" represents "that person's name." AT: "I will erase that person's name from my book" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This refers to the book of Yahweh that Moses spoke of in [[:en:bible:notes:exo:32:30|32:32]].

tn.ref: But on the day that I punish them, I will punish them
tn.text: On the day that God decides to punish them, it will be clear that it is God who is judging them.

tn.ref: Yahweh sent a plague on the people
tn.text: This plague may have been a serious illness. AT: "Yahweh made the people very sick"

tn.ref: they had made the calf, the one that Aaron made
tn.text: Even though Aaron made the calf, the people were also guilty because they told Aaron to do it. AT: "they told Aaron to make the calf"
